title: Arrays: Collections of Data
description: Work with arrays to store and manipulate multiple values of the same type

concepts.title: Array Fundamentals
concepts.content:
An array is a collection of elements of the same data type stored in contiguous memory locations. Arrays allow you to store multiple values in a single variable, making it much easier to work with groups of related data.

When you declare an array, you specify the data type of the elements, the name of the array, and the number of elements it will hold. For example, int numbers[5]; declares an array named numbers that can hold 5 integers. The number in square brackets is called the array size or dimension.

Array elements are accessed using an index, which starts at 0 for the first element. So in a 5-element array, valid indices are 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4. To access the third element, you use numbers[2]. Using an invalid index (like numbers[5] in a 5-element array) causes undefined behavior and can crash your program or produce incorrect results.

You can initialize an array when you declare it by providing values in curly braces. For example, int numbers[3] = {10, 20, 30}; creates an array with three elements initialized to these values. If you provide fewer values than the array size, the remaining elements are initialized to zero.

Arrays are stored in memory as contiguous blocks, meaning each element is stored right next to the previous one. This makes arrays very efficient for accessing elements, as the computer can calculate the exact memory location of any element instantly. Arrays are fundamental data structures used extensively in programming for storing lists, tables, and sequences of data.

concepts.title: Iterating Through Arrays
concepts.content:
One of the most common operations with arrays is iterating through them using loops. This allows you to process each element systematically.

The for loop is perfect for arrays because you know exactly how many iterations you needâ€”one for each array element. You can use the loop counter as the array index. A typical pattern is: for (int i = 0; i < size; i++) which accesses elements from index 0 to size-1.

When iterating through an array, you must ensure you don't exceed the array bounds. If an array has 5 elements (indices 0-4) and you try to access index 5, you'll access memory beyond the array, which is undefined behavior. C doesn't automatically check bounds, so you must be careful.

You can iterate through an entire array to find specific values, calculate statistics (like sum or average), or modify all elements. For example, to sum all elements in an array, you initialize a variable to 0 and add each element to it in a loop.

Understanding how to work with arrays through loops is essential because arrays and loops are used together constantly in real programs. Most real-world programming involves processing collections of data, which is exactly what array iteration does.

concepts.title: Multidimensional Arrays
concepts.content:
While one-dimensional arrays store a single list of elements, multidimensional arrays store data in multiple dimensions. The most common is the 2D array, which is like a table with rows and columns.

You declare a 2D array by specifying two dimensions: int matrix[3][4]; creates an array with 3 rows and 4 columns. You can think of this as 3 rows, each containing 4 elements.

To access an element in a 2D array, you use two indices: matrix[row][col]. For example, matrix[0][0] is the element in the first row and first column, while matrix[2][3] is the element in the third row and fourth column.

You can initialize a 2D array with nested braces: int matrix[2][3] = {{1, 2, 3}, {4, 5, 6}};. This creates a 2x3 matrix with the specified values.

To iterate through a 2D array, you use nested loops. The outer loop iterates through rows, and the inner loop iterates through columns. This gives you access to every element in the array.

2D arrays are useful for representing tables, game boards, matrices, and any data that naturally has a row-column structure. Understanding multidimensional arrays opens up possibilities for more complex data organization.
